Chase_Rice:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter and football player}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2019}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Chase Rice | image = Chase Rice - cropped.jpg | caption = Rice in 2016 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|9|19}}
[[Ormond Beach, Florida]] | origin = [[Asheville, North Carolina]], U.S. | instrument = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Country pop]]|[[country rock]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}} | years_active = 2010â€“present | label = {{hlist|Dack Janiels|[[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]]|[[BBR Music Group|BBR]]}} | website = {{URL|chaserice.com}} }} '''Chase Rice''' (born September 19, 1985{{cite news|last1=Casey|first1=Jim|title=Chase Rice Might talk New Single, Wikipedia Errors and Showing More "Depth" With an Upcoming Album|url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2016/07/01/chase-rice-talks-new-single-wikipedia-errors-and-showing-more-depth-with-upcoming-album/|access-date=July 2, 2016|work=Nash Country Daily|date=July 1, 2016}}) is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter and reality television personality. He first came to prominence in 2010 while he was a contestant on ''[[Survivor: Nicaragua]]'', where he was the runner-up to [[Jud Birza|Jud "Fabio" Birza]]. In the same year Rice began focusing on a career in country music, and later co-wrote the diamond-certified single "[[Cruise (song)|Cruise]]", performed by [[Florida Georgia Line]]. Rice has released six studio albums, and his third album, ''[[Ignite the Night]]'', debuted atop the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6236407/chase-rice-country-albums-number-one|title=Chase Rice|date=August 28, 2014|magazine=Billboard|access-date=October 21, 2014}} He has also scored two number-one singles on the [[Country Airplay]] chart with "[[Eyes on You (Chase Rice song)|Eyes on You]]"{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8510439/chase-rice-eyes-on-you-no-1-country-airplay|title=Chase Rice Lands First Country Airplay No. 1 With 'Eyes On You'|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2019-08-28}} and "[[Drinkin' Beer. Talkin' God. Amen.]]" (featuring Florida Georgia Line). Prior to 2010, Rice was a former [[college football]] [[linebacker]] for the [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina Tar Heels]] and a former [[NASCAR]] [[pit crew]] member for [[Hendrick Motorsports]]. ==Early life, education, and early career== Born in Florida, Rice was raised on a farm in [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. He attended [[AC Reynolds High School]]{{cite web|title=Chase Rice Biography|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_6037395,00.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130124135747/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_6037395,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 24, 2013|work=Artists|publisher=Great American Country}} and the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] where he was a linebacker on the [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|football team]]. He did not pursue an [[National Football League|NFL]] career due to injury.{{cite news|last=Dauphin|first=Chuck|title=Spotlight: Ex-'Survivor' Star Chase Rice Debuts Big With 'Dirt Road Communion'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/488389/spotlight-ex-survivor-star-chase-rice-debuts-big-with-dirt-road|newspaper=Billboard|date=May 16, 2012}}{{cite news|last1=Fadorski|first1=Kelli Skye|title=From a NASCAR pit crew member to 'Survivor' star, Chase Rice still prefers country music|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/rice-745140-country-really.html|access-date=February 28, 2017|work=[[Orange County Register]]|date=February 28, 2017}} After graduating from UNC, Rice was selected to join the [[Hendrick Motorsports]] [[pit crew]] as the rear tire carrier for [[Ryan Newman (racing driver)|Ryan Newman]]'s [[Nationwide Series]] car. He also worked on [[Jimmie Johnson]]'s [[Sprint Cup Series]] car and won two championships with the [[Lowe's]] team.{{cite web|title=Chase Rice|url=http://hillcountry.com/dc/music-calendar/single-event/189543/|publisher=Hill Country BBQ, Washington, D.C.|access-date=March 5, 2016}}{{Dead link|date=July 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==''Survivor''== Rice was selected as a cast member of the [[reality television]] show ''[[Survivor: Nicaragua]]''. He said that he was able to get his application into [[CBS]] through a college friend who had a connection with the network.{{cite news|title=Exclusive: 'Survivor: Nicaragua' runner-up Chase Rice talks|url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/exclusive-survivor-nicaragua-runner-up-chase-rice-talks-11830.php|newspaper=Reality TV World|date=December 22, 2012}} Rice was originally on the La Flor tribe, consisting of younger contestants. During his time on the tribe, he was quickly attracted to fellow contestant Brenda Lowe, who became aware of his attraction and used it to her advantage, recruiting him and several others into an alliance. After La Flor won three of the first four tribal immunity challenges, the tribes were blended and Rice ended up on the new version of the original "older contestants" tribe, Espada, while Lowe remained on the new version of the La Flor tribe. Rice and Lowe both ultimately made it to the merged group, Libertad, where their alliance successfully caused the eliminations of Alina Wilson and Marty Piombo, before turning on Lowe and eliminating her as a threat. Following Lowe's elimination, Rice continued with the alliance under new leader Matthew "Sash" Lenahan. After two contestants (NaOnka Mixon and "Purple Kelly" Shinn) quit, the alliance continued eliminating targets Ben "Benry" Henry, Jane Bright, Dan Lembo, and Holly Hoffman, although Bright and Hoffman were members of the alliance. The alliance tried to eliminate [[Jud Birza|Jud "Fabio" Birza]] as a threat against the jury, but Birza managed to evade them by winning the last three immunity challenges. Rice performed exceptionally well in the post-merge challenges, being on the winning team in two of the three team-oriented rewards, and winning the last two individual rewards. Eventually, Rice made it to the final three with Lenahan and Birza, where he had a chance to win the $1 million as "Sole Survivor". In pleading his case to the jury, Rice claimed that he was being open about how he played the game, but was criticized both for his rash decisions and occasional indecisiveness, as well as being perceived as a follower under both Lowe and Lenahan. Although both Rice and Lenahan tried to accuse Birza of not knowing what was going on in the competition, the jury still ultimately chose Birza who received five of the nine votes; Rice received the votes of Hoffman, Bright, Lowe, and Wilson. On the nationally televised reunion show, Rice played his single "Buzz Back".{{cite web|last=Wilkening|first=Matthew|title='Survivor' Finalist Chase Rice Debuts Country Song on Season Finale|date=December 20, 2010 |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/survivor-finalist-chase-rice-country-song-season-finale/|publisher=Taste of Country}} Although he received national media attention on the show, he says that reality show stardom did not help propel his country music career; instead, he cited it as an important life event that was more valuable than money and that put his life in perspective. In the official issue of ''[[CBS Watch]]'' magazine, commemorating the 15th anniversary of ''[[Survivor (TV series)|Survivor]]'' in 2015, Rice was voted by viewers as the 10th "steamiest" male contestant in ''Survivor'' history.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/DaltonRoss/status/565168330513080320 |title=Wait, where's @JohnMCochran? |publisher=Twitter |first=Dalton |last=Ross |date=February 10, 2015 |access-date=February 10, 2015}} ==Country music career== [[File:Chase Rice Mojo Club 2020.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Rice in 2020]] Chase Rice began playing guitar in college. He cites his father as the inspiration for his career, recalling his father saying "boy anyone can play guitar, but no one is gonna really listen to you until you start singing." He creates his albums based on the live shows he has and is building his career through performing. His first studio album, ''Friday Nights & Sunday Mornings'', was released on April 22, 2010. This 13-track album includes the first song he ever wrote/recorded, "Larger Than Life", which is about the passing of his father. This is the only full-length album Rice has released that is not available for digital purchase or streaming. In March 2011, he released ''Country as Me'', a six-track EP featuring his single "Buzz Back". He has received air play as a "Highway Find" on satellite radio channel [[The Highway (Sirius XM)|The Highway]]. In April 2012, his second studio album ''[[Dirt Road Communion]]'' debuted at number 48 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard charts|Country Albums]] chart. This album included the original recordings of "Jack Daniels and Jesus" and "How She Rolls", the latter of which has been removed from streaming and digital platforms in its original form. "Whoa" has also been removed from all digital and streaming platforms, but was never re-released leaving the current total tracks on the album at 14. "Happy Hour (Worktape)" includes a hidden track, "Kiss My Ass", which begins at the 4:31 minute mark on the song. In July 2012, he signed with [[Creative Artists Agency]].{{cite news|title=Indie artist Chase Rice Signs with CAA|url=http://nashvillecountryclub.com/News.php?id=4177|newspaper=Nashville Country Club|date=July 19, 2012|access-date=December 31, 2012|archive-date=January 3, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190103005104/http://nashvillecountryclub.com/News.php?id=4177|url-status=dead}} He was a co-writer of [[Florida Georgia Line]]'s "[[Cruise (song)|Cruise]]" which topped ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]].{{cite web|title=Chase Rice 'Cruise's with Florida Georgia Line to Platinum Success and a #1 Single|url=http://www.gotcountryonline.com/chase-rice-cruises-with-florida-georgia-line-to-platinum-success-and-a-1-single/|publisher=Got Country Online|access-date=December 28, 2012}} In October 2013, he released ''[[Ready Set Roll (EP)|Ready Set Roll]]'', a six-song EP including the title track. The physical version of the album was released in November 2013 and included the bonus song "Jack Daniel's and Jesus". On January 29, 2014, the official "[[Ready Set Roll]]" music video premiered exclusively on CMT.{{cite web|url=http://chaserice.com/103-official-ready-set-roll-music-video-premieres-on-cmt|title=Official Ready Set Roll Music Video Premieres on CMT |access-date=February 4, 2016 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221113825/http://chaserice.com/103-official-ready-set-roll-music-video-premieres-on-cmt |archive-date=February 21, 2014 }} The next day the video debuted on VEVO. He partnered with [[Columbia Records]] for distribution of "Ready Set Roll" in March 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2014/03/columbia-nashville-inks-strategic-partnership-with-chase-rice/|title=Columbia Nashville Inks Strategic Partnership With Chase Rice|work=MusicRow - Nashville's Music Industry Publication - News, Songs From Music City|date=March 27, 2014 |access-date=October 21, 2014}} On June 30, 2014, Rice released the album cover, release date, and album sequence for ''[[Ignite the Night]]''. The full-length album was released on August 19, 2014, and included the platinum-certified single, "Ready Set Roll". In February 2016, Rice released "Whisper", which was intended to be the lead single from an upcoming album. The song was unsuccessful commercially, peaking at number 56 on the week of April 23, 2016, after just 3 weeks of being on the Country Airplay chart.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/299025/chase-rice/chart?f=1226 |title=Chase Rice - Chart history |magazine=Billboard |access-date=July 31, 2016}} It is currently the single which has peaked the lowest for Rice only behind "How She Rolls" which peaked at number 55 in 2013, and never received real label backing. After releasing the single, Rice issued a letter to his fans which said, "If you have listened to my music for years and want to hear more depth and meaning, I very much appreciate you, too, and your desires will also be fulfilled on this album (and truthfully, that was my goal on previous albums with songs like "Carolina Can" and "Every Song I Sing")." He went on to mention that he was influenced by [[Garth Brooks]] and [[Kenny Chesney]].{{cite web|url=https://countrymusicrocks.net/2016/02/chase-rice-pens-honest-and-heartfelt-letter-to-fans.html/|title=Chase Rice Pens Honest and Heartfelt Letter to Fans|date=February 5, 2016|website=Country Music Rocks|language=en-US|access-date=December 1, 2021}} Rice then released "Everybody We Know Does", which was sent to country radio on June 24, 2016.{{cite web|author=Lauren Laffer|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/chase-rice-releases-new-single-everybody-we-know-does/ |title=Chase Rice Releases New Single, 'Everybody We Know Does' Sounds Like Nashville |publisher=Soundslikenashville.com |date=June 24, 2016 |access-date=July 31, 2016}} After "Everybody We Know Does" failed to crack the top 25, Rice left Columbia in 2017 and signed to [[BBR Music Group|Broken Bow Records]] the same year. The lead single from Rice's first album with BBR, "Three Chords and the Truth", was sent to country radio.{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/chase-rice-bbr-music-group-broken-bow-records/|title=Chase Rice Signs With Broken Bow, Ready to Release New Music|website=The Boot|date=June 21, 2017 |access-date=December 10, 2017}} This single was highly praised by both country fans and radio, as this was his first single to crack the Top 25 on the [[Country Airplay]] chart in 4 years. ''Lambs & Lions'' is Rice's first album on Broken Bow Records/BMG and is also the first album released by BBR since the BMG takeover. The album was released on November 17, 2017. Rice's single "[[Eyes on You (Chase Rice song)|Eyes on You]]" became his first number one on country radio on May 6, 2019, staying at the top for two weeks.{{cite web |last1=Stevens |first1=Buck |title=Chase Rice Holds Number One for Second Week with "Eyes On You" |url=http://www.wbwn.com/2019/05/13/chase-rice-holds-number-one-for-second-week-with-eyes-on-you/ |website=wbwn.com |date=May 13, 2019 |access-date=23 May 2019}} He then released the follow-up single "[[Lonely If You Are]]" on July 1, 2019.{{cite web | url=https://www.thecountrydaily.com/2019/06/07/chase-rice-drops-friendly-new-single-lonely-if-you-are-listen/ | title=Chase Rice Drops Friendly New Single, "Lonely If You Are" [Listen] | publisher=The Country Daily | date=June 7, 2019 | access-date=September 22, 2020 | author=Jim Casey}} Rice also wrote and performed the inaugural theme song for ''[[The Pat McAfee Show]]'', which was used from September 10, 2019, to April 30, 2020.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ie1pN5HscGk|title=The Pat McAfee Show - Tuesday September 10th|date=September 10, 2019|via=YouTube}}
{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxZCaGmkDTI|title=The Pat McAfee Show - Thursday, April 30th|date=April 30, 2020|via=YouTube}} Rice appeared on the fourth episode of [[The Bachelor (season 24)|season 24 of ''The Bachelor'']], performing at a private concert for bachelor [[Peter Weber (television personality)|Peter Weber]] and his date, Victoria Fuller, at [[Cedar Point]] in [[Sandusky, Ohio]]. Fuller later revealed that she had previously dated Rice.{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/tv/2020/01/27/the-bachelor-chase-rice-claims-he-didnt-expect-perform-ex/4594060002/|title=Singer Chase Rice expresses frustration over the 'drama' he was dragged into on 'The Bachelor'|last=Trepany|first=Charles|website=USA TODAY|language=en-US|access-date=2020-01-29}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/28/entertainment/chase-rice-bachelor-trnd/index.html|title=Chase Rice claims 'Bachelor' producers blindsided him with his ex-girlfriend on latest episode|first=Marianne |last=Garvey|website=CNN|date=January 28, 2020 |access-date=2020-01-29}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/2020/01/cedar-point-episode-of-the-bachelor-was-a-cold-blustery-lesson-in-reality-and-it-wasnt-pretty.html|title=Cedar Point episode of 'The Bachelor' was a cold, blustery lesson in reality . . . and it wasn't pretty|first=Chuck|last=Yarborough|work=The Plain Dealer|date=2020-01-27|language=en|access-date=2020-01-29}} On June 27, 2020, Rice played a concert at the [[Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary]], in [[Petros, Tennessee]], where many fans chose to ignore recommended safety measures against spreading and contracting [[COVID-19]]. Reaction to the concert drew negative outcry from fans and the music industry.{{Cite web|date=2020-06-29|title=As COVID-19 surges, country star Chase Rice plays packed concert for a thousand mask-free fans|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2020-06-28/chase-rice-country-concert-covid-19|access-date=2020-06-29|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US}} In response to the criticism Rice stated: "If it were up to me I wouldn't cancel one damn show, but it ain't.... I personally, choose not to live scared, especially of something that I can't really control."{{Cite news|date=2020-06-30|title=Country singers criticize Chase Rice as 'selfish' for concert in front of hundreds in Tennessee|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2020/06/29/chase-rice-concert-social-distancing-tennessee/#comments-wrapper|language=en-US}} In November 2020, Rice released the single "[[Drinkin' Beer. Talkin' God. Amen.]]" featuring his long-time friends Florida Georgia Line.{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamwindsor/2020/11/30/chase-rice-teams-up-with-florida-georgia-line-for-new-song-drinkin-beer-talkin-god-amen/?sh=60409295c39e| title=Chase Rice Teams Up With Florida Georgia Line For New Song 'Drinkin' Beer Talkin' God Amen'| work=[[Forbes]]| date=November 30, 2020| access-date=December 4, 2020 |first=Pam|last=Windsor}} It is the second single from Rice's fifth studio album, ''[[The Album (Chase Rice album)|The Album]]'', which was released on May 28, 2021.{{cite news |url=https://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations|accessdate=May 29, 2021|work=AllAccess}} In November 2022, Rice announced his sixth studio album ''I Hate Cowboys & All Dogs Go to Hell'', which was released in February 2023.{{cite web|url=https://www.wfms.com/news/chase-rice-announces-new-album-i-hate-cowboys-all-dogs-go-to-hell/|title=Chase Rice Announces New Album 'I Hate Cowboys & All Dogs Go To Hell'|website=[[WFMS]]|date=November 20, 2022|access-date=February 9, 2023|archive-date=November 21, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221121045120/https://www.wfms.com/news/chase-rice-announces-new-album-i-hate-cowboys-all-dogs-go-to-hell/|url-status=dead}}{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/chase-rice-album-interview-i-hate-cowboys-1235251656/|title=Chase Rice Finds His True Voice On New Album 'I Hate Cowboys & All Dogs Go to Hell'|work=Forbes|first=Pam|last=Windsor|date=February 20, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}} The sole single from the album, "Bad Day to Be a Cold Beer",{{cite web|url=https://www.bbrmusicgroup.com/chase-rice-delivers-summer-anthem-bad-day-cold-beer-country-radio/|title=CHASE RICE DELIVERS SUMMER ANTHEM "BAD DAY TO BE A COLD BEER" TO COUNTRY RADIO|website=bbrmusicgroup.com|date=May 8, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}} was released in May and music videos were produced for "Bench Seat", "Way Down Yonder" and "I Hate Cowboys".{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/chase-rice-album-interview-i-hate-cowboys-1235251656/|title=Chase Rice Refines His Artistic Voice on New Album: 'I'm Not Chasing Anything Anymore'|work=Billboard|first=Jessica|last=Nicholson|date=February 10, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}} During the year, Rice promoted the album on the Way Down Yonder tour,{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/chase-rice-2023-way-down-yonder-tour-dates/|title=Chase Rice Will Showcase New Album on 2023 Way Down Yonder Tour|work=Taste of Country|author=Jess|date=December 13, 2022|access-date=October 24, 2023}} and was a supporting act for [[Jelly Roll (singer)|Jelly Roll]] and [[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]].{{cite web|url=https://countrynow.com/jelly-roll-facetimes-ashley-mcbryde-chase-rice-more-to-make-big-announcement/|title=Jelly Roll FaceTimes Ashley McBryde, Chase Rice & More To Make Big Announcement|work=Country Now|first=Lauren Jo|last=Black|date=February 20, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}}{{cite web|url=https://countrynow.com/old-dominion-extends-no-bad-vibes-tour-with-new-arena-shows-and-special-guests/|title=Old Dominion Extends No Bad Vibes Tour With New Arena Shows And Special Guests|work=Country Now|first=Madeleine|last=O'Connell|date=May 2, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}} In early 2024, Rice will embark on his headlining "Get Western Tour" across Canada and the [[Pacific Northwest]], with [[Owen Riegling]] and Palmer Anthony as supporting acts.{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2023/11/chase-rice-to-head-up-north-for-get-western-tour/|title=Chase Rice To Head Up North For â€˜Get Western Tourâ€™|date=November 22, 2023|first=Lorie|last=Hollabaugh|work=Music Row|access-date=December 25, 2023}} ==Discography== {{main|Chase Rice discography}} *''Friday
